item.title: Jabs to be compulsory for England care home staff
item.description: Workers are expected be given 16 weeks to have the jab - or risk losing their job, the BBC understands.

item.title: Boris Johnson called health secretary hopeless in WhatsApp message - Dominic Cummings
item.description: The PM's former aide launches a fresh tirade in his war of words with Health Secretary Matt Hancock.

item.title: Another life-saving Covid treatment found
item.description: Monoclonal antibody therapy, given by drip, can save some of the sickest hospital patients.

item.title: Nóra Quoirin death: Inquest ruling changed to open verdict
item.description: A judge alters the inquest verdict in the death of the 15-year-old who went missing in a Malaysian jungle.

item.title: Duke's death left giant-sized hole in our lives - Sophie
item.description: In an interview, the Countess of Wessex says the Covid pandemic made it harder to support the Queen.

item.title: Israel strikes in Gaza after fire balloons launched
item.description: It is the first major flare-up since a ceasefire ended a conflict between Israel and Hamas in May.

item.title: Euro 2020: Wales aim to silence Turkey's 'home' crowd in Baku
item.description: Wales will aim to "silence" what will effectively be a home crowd for Turkey when they meet in Baku for their second match of Euro 2020.

item.title: UK warned it is unprepared for climate chaos
item.description: Homes need to be more resilient and the government is in a worse position than five years ago, report says.

item.title: Tenerife: Protests against violence as search for baby's body continues
item.description: The body of a child is found in the sea off Tenerife, but her sister remains missing, feared murdered.

item.title: Man charged after BBC reporter chased by protesters
item.description: A clip shared on social media shows demonstrators haranguing BBC Newsnight reporter Nicholas Watt.

item.title: Mother designs cards for babies of colour due to 'lack of representation'
item.description: Deborah Ajaja struggled to find milestone cards that matched her child’s heritage, so she created her own.

item.title: Covid: How have allotments helped people during the pandemic?
item.description: Plot-holders tell how growing their own has helped them deal with grief and sustain mental health.

item.title: Ex-England captain reunites with dad with Parkinson's
item.description: The year Mike Tindall won the Rugby World Cup was the same year his father received his diagnosis.

item.title: Boy, 9, writes plea to PM for epileptic brother's cannabis treatment
item.description: Thomas Braun's younger brother has up to 100 epileptic seizures a day.

item.title: Euro 2020: Scotland fan visits streets named after every player
item.description: 20-year-old David visits 26 streets around the UK that share a name with a Scotland footballer.

item.title: Drone cameras record social lives of killer whales
item.description: A new study suggests killer whales may socialise with each other based on age and gender.

item.title: The Papers: 'No green light to jab kids' and Met police 'rotten'
item.description: Delays to vaccinations for children and mandatory jabs for care home staff feature on the front pages.

item.title: Barbara Windsor's Carry on Camping bikini sells for £9,500
item.description: The swimsuit, worn by the late actress in a famous Carry on Camping scene, raises money for charity.

item.title: Isles of Scilly: Egyptian vulture seen in UK for first time in 150 years
item.description: The sighting of the Egyptian vulture, if confirmed to be wild, would be the first for 153 years.

item.title: Sophie, Countess of Wessex, weeps as she remembers Duke of Edinburgh
item.description: Sophie, Countess of Wessex, tells 5 Live about the "giant-sized hole" the Duke of Edinburgh’s death has left in the Royal family.

item.title: British music exports reach a record high
item.description: Artists like Dua Lipa, Coldplay and The Beatles help the British music industry make £500m overseas.

item.title: E3 2021: Nintendo shows off more Zelda Breath of the Wild 2
item.description: A last-minute Zelda segment capped a Nintendo showcase which left some fans disappointed.

item.title: What are the Delta variant symptoms?
item.description: The Delta variant of Covid-19, first identified in India, has changed how the virus is spreading.

item.title: Iran election: Who will voters choose as president?
item.description: Seven men are competing to become president but most reformist and centrist candidates are barred from standing.

item.title: ‘I got PTSD after witnessing my daughter’s birth’
item.description: After the distressing birth of his daughter, Elliott Rae struggled with post traumatic stress disorder.

item.title: 'People didn't believe my CV', says board director
item.description: Women still face difficulties getting onto boards at smaller firms, according to research.

item.title: Biden: How Europeans have reacted to president's visit
item.description: Three prominent Europeans assess how Joe Biden's talks with European leaders have gone.

item.title: Brexit: Can the UK and the EU reach a deal on Northern Ireland?
item.description: How might the UK and EU compromise on the Northern Ireland protocol?

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'I started my firm for under £500 as a bet'
item.description: Snack boss Nick Coleman started his firm for under £500 as a bet. It now turns over £6m a year.

item.title: 'I never dreamed I was entitled to benefits'
item.description: Older people facing poverty are urged to claim Pension Credit - a gateway to further financial help.

item.title: How many people can come to a party now? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Tracking change in Ethiopia and the challenges ahead
item.description: The BBC charts the dramatic changes and challenges facing the country as it goes to the polls.

item.title: Maisie Peters: Meet the singer who's been snapped up by Ed Sheeran
item.description: Get to know the 21-year-old whose debut album will be coming out on Ed Sheeran's record label.

item.title: Champions Man City face Spurs - who do your team play on Premier League opening weekend?
item.description: Champions Manchester City face a testing trip to Spurs on the opening weekend of the new Premier League season.

item.title: Euro 2020: Watch ‘superstar’ Ronaldo’s historic double for Portugal
item.description: Portugal's Cristiano Ronaldo makes history by becoming the all-time leading goalscorer in the European Championship after scoring a brace versus Hungary in front of a capacity crowd in Budapest.

item.title: Fury v Wilder III: Tyson Fury and Deontay Wilder preview third fight
item.description: WBC world heavyweight champion Tyson Fury and American challenger Deontay Wilder's press conference, to preview their third fight on 24 July in Las Vegas, was a little unusual.

item.title: Euro 2020: 'A little bit untoward' - Did Germany defender Rudiger bite Pogba?
item.description: BBC pundits Alex Scott and Robert Green question if Germany's Antonio Rudiger may have bitten the shoulder of France midfielder Paul Pogba.

item.title: US-Russia relations: Adversary or potential partner?
item.description: Three young Americans and three young Russians spoke to the BBC about the other country.

item.title: Three things to watch as Joe Biden meets Vladimir Putin
item.description: The US president is set to talk to the Russian leader in Geneva, Switzerland, on Wednesday.

item.title: What Putin really wants from Biden
item.description: The Geneva summit on 16 June between the Russian and US presidents will not be a friendly encounter.

item.title: 'I would like Russia to be more free'
item.description: The BBC's Steve Rosenberg travels 2,000 miles east of Moscow to gauge the mood of ordinary Russians.

item.title: The Beast: How Biden's getting around on his first overseas trip
item.description: Planes, helicopters and armoured cars - how President Biden will travel on his first official trip.

item.title: Covid symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms that mean you may have coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Over 40s in England and Scotland can have their second dose after eight weeks instead of 12.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being surge tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go... and who with?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Wearing a face covering is currently a legal requirement in many places, but could the rules change as lockdown eases further?

item.title: Coronavirus G7: Could a billion more vaccines for poorer countries make a difference?
item.description: How much difference could the G7 offer of a billion vaccines make to tackling the pandemic?

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The government has said some restrictions will stay in place in England after 21 June.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and can I hold a reception?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - so how can you now celebrate?

item.title: What are the rules for pubs, restaurants, festivals and gigs?
item.description: The lifting of restrictions in England has been delayed, which could affect planned events

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 41 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: What are the social distancing rules and when could they end?
item.description: Will we still need to be socially distanced through the summer? A social distancing review is advising the government.

item.title: Covid: Is there a limit to how much worse variants can get?
item.description: The coronavirus has changed and changed again, getting more transmissible each time.

item.title: Covid symptoms: Is it a cold or coronavirus?
item.description: With similar symptoms, deciding whether or not you need to get tested for coronavirus can be tricky.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid: How should I protect myself from Covid now?
item.description: What are the actions we can take to reduce our risk of catching the virus?

item.title: Lockdown easing: Four numbers to look for ahead of the 21 June decision
item.description: The key numbers that offer clues as to whether "freedom day" will proceed as planned on 21 June.
